page_title: Create a static host catalog
description: >-
  Use static host catalogs to manually define a set of hosts within Boundary. Create a static host catalog and hosts.

# Static host catalogs

A static host catalog allows you to manually define a collection that can include hosts or host sets.

[Dynamic host catalogs](/boundary/docs/hosts/index#automated-host-discovery-in-boundary) allow you to sync hosts from a cloud provider.

@include 'configuration-reference/domain-model/host-catalog-structure.mdx'

After defining a host catalog, you can then create [targets](/boundary/docs/domain-model/targets) to connect to these hosts using a Boundary [session](/boundary/docs/domain-model/sessions). Targets define the port and protocol that should be used for a session. This means a single host can have multiple targets defined if it accepts connections on different ports. For example, a host can have an SSH target listening on port `22`, and also accept connections on port `5432` from a postgres client. To assign a host to a target, you must add the host to a host set.

## Create a static host catalog

Complete the following steps to create a static host catalog.

<Tabs>
<Tab heading="Admin Console" group="admin">

1. Log in to Boundary.
1. Select the org, and then select the project you want to create a host catalog for.
1. Select **Host Catalogs**.
1. Select **New Host Catalog**.
1. Complete the following fields:
   - **Name**: (Optional) An optional name for identification purposes.
   If you enter a name, it must be unique.
   - **Description**: (Optional) An optional description of the host catalog for identification purposes.
   - **Type**: (Required) Select **Static** to create a static host catalog.
1. Click **Save**.

</Tab>
<Tab heading="CLI" group="cli">

1. Log in to Boundary.
1. Set the `BOUNDARY_PROJECT_ID` environment variable, or provide the scope ID (such as `p_1234567890`) in the next step.
1. Use the following command to create a static host catalog named `my-host-catalog`:

   ```shell-session
   $ boundary host-catalogs create static \
     -scope-id $BOUNDARY_PROJECT_ID \
     -name "my-host-catalog"
   ```

  You must provide the `scope-id` field when you create a static host catalog.

  Refer to the [host catalogs](/boundary/docs/domain-model/host-catalogs) domain model documentation for more fields that you can use when you create host catalogs.

</Tab>
<Tab heading="Terraform" group="terraform">

You can define a host catalog using the [Boundary Terraform provider](https://registry.terraform.io/providers/hashicorp/boundary/latest):

```hcl
resource "boundary_host_catalog_static" "my_catalog" {
  name        = "my-host-catalog"
  description = "A static host catalog"
  scope_id    = boundary_scope.project.id
}
```

</Tab>
</Tabs>

## Create hosts

Complete the following steps to create a static host within a static host catalog.

<Tabs>
<Tab heading="Admin Console" group="admin">

1. Select **Host Catalogs**.
1. Select a static host catalog.
1. Click the **Hosts** tab, and click **New**.
1. Complete the following fields:
    - **Name**: (Optional) An optional name for identification purposes.
    If you enter a name, it must be unique.
    - **Description**: (Optional) An optional description of the host catalog for identification purposes.
    - **Address**: (Required) The host address, without specifying a protocol.
1. Click **Save**.

</Tab>
<Tab heading="CLI" group="cli">

```shell-session
$ boundary hosts create static \
  -name "my-host" \
  -description "My static host" \
  -host-catalog-id hcst_1234567890 \
  -address "10.0.0.1"
```

</Tab>
<Tab heading="Terraform" group="terraform">

```hcl
resource "boundary_host_static" "my_host" {
  name            = "my-host"
  description     = "My static host"
  address         = "10.0.0.1"
  host_catalog_id = boundary_host_catalog_static.my_catalog.id
}
```

</Tab>
</Tabs>

## Create a host set

Complete the following steps to create a static host set containing a static host.

<Tabs>
<Tab heading="Admin Console" group="admin">

1. Log in to Boundary.
1. Select the org, and then select the project you want to create a host set for.
1. Select **Host Catalogs**.
1. Select a host catalog.
1. Click the **Host Sets** tab, and then click **New**.
1. Complete the following fields:
    - **Name**: (Optional) An optional name for identification purposes.
    If you enter a name, it must be unique.
    - **Description**: (Optional) An optional description of the host catalog for identification purposes.
1. Click **Save**.

</Tab>
<Tab heading="CLI" group="cli">

Create a static host set:

```shell-session
$ boundary host-sets create static \
  -name "my-host-set" \
  -description "My host set" \
  -host-catalog-id hcst_1234567890
```

Add hosts to a host set:

```shell-session
$ boundary host-sets add-hosts \
  -id hsst_1234567890 \
  -host hst_1234567890 \
  -host hst_0987654321
```

</Tab>
<Tab heading="Terraform" group="terraform">

To define this host set in Terraform:

```hcl
resource "boundary_host_set_static" "my_host_set" {
  type            = "static"
  name            = "my-host-set"
  description     = "My host set"
  host_catalog_id = "hcst_1234567890"
  host_ids = [ boundary_host_static.my_host.id ]
}
```

</Tab>
</Tabs>

## Example

In this example you will create three hosts for separate databases. One for a hypothetical MySQL database running on `192.168.0.10` at port `3306`, a second for another MySQL database running on `192.168.0.11` at port `3306`, and a third for a Postgres database running on `192.168.0.20` at port `5432`.

**Host catalog:**

1. `databases`

**Hosts:**

1. `mysql1`:
   - Host address is `192.168.0.10`
   - Availability port is `3306`
1. `mysql2`:
   - Host address is `192.168.0.11`
   - Availability port is `3306`
1. `postgres`:
   - Host address is `192.168.0.20`
   - Availability port is `5432`

**Host sets:**

1. `mysql-hosts`
   - Hosts: `mysql1` and `mysql2`
1. `postgres-hosts`
   - Hosts: `postgres`

The `databases` host catalog will contain the `mysql-hosts` host set and the `postgres-hosts` host set. The `mysql-hosts` host set contains the `mysql1` and `mysql2` hosts, and the `postgres-hosts` host set contains the `postgres` host.

### Create the databases host catalog

Complete the following steps to create a static host catalog named `databases`.

<Tabs>
<Tab heading="Admin Console" group="admin">

1. Log in to Boundary.
1. Select the org, and then select the project you want to create a host catalog for.
1. Select **Host Catalogs**.
1. Select **New Host Catalog**.
1. Complete the following fields:
   - **Name**: `databases` (Optional) An optional name for identification purposes.
   If you enter a name, it must be unique.
   - **Description**: (Optional) An optional description of the host catalog for identification purposes.
   - **Type**: (Required) Select **Static** to create a static host catalog.
1. Click **Save**.

</Tab>
<Tab heading="CLI" group="cli">

1. Log in to Boundary.
1. Set the `BOUNDARY_PROJECT_ID` environment variable, or provide the scope ID (such as `p_1234567890`) in the next step.
1. Use the following command to create a static host catalog named `databases`:

   ```shell-session
   $ boundary host-catalogs create static \
     -scope-id $BOUNDARY_PROJECT_ID \
     -name "databases"
   ```

  You must provide the `scope-id` field when you create a static host catalog.

  Refer to the [host catalogs](/boundary/docs/domain-model/host-catalogs) domain model documentation for more fields that you can use when you create host catalogs.

</Tab>
<Tab heading="Terraform" group="terraform">

You can define a host catalog using the [Boundary Terraform provider](https://registry.terraform.io/providers/hashicorp/boundary/latest):

```hcl
resource "boundary_host_catalog_static" "databases" {
  name        = "databases"
  description = "A host catalog for all database types"
  scope_id    = boundary_scope.project.id
}
```

</Tab>
</Tabs>

### Create the MySQL and Postgres host sets

Host sets allow you to group hosts that provide equivalent services together. When a target references a host set, it selects any host from the set to establish a connection, unless you configure a [target alias](/boundary/docs/targets/configuration/create-target-alias) to use a specific host ID.

You must create hosts in a host catalog. Hosts must belong to a host set to add them to a target.

#### Create the MySQL host set

In this example, you first create a host set named `mysql-hosts` for the `mysql1` and `mysql2` hosts.

<Tabs>
<Tab heading="Admin Console" group="admin">

1. Log in to Boundary.
1. Select the org, and then select the project you want to create a host set for.
1. Select **Host Catalogs**.
1. Select the **databases** host catalog.
1. Click the **Host Sets** tab, and then click **New**.
1. Complete the following fields:
    - **Name**: `mysql-hosts` (Optional) An optional name for identification purposes.
    If you enter a name, it must be unique.
    - **Description**: (Optional) An optional description of the host catalog for identification purposes.
1. Click **Save**.

</Tab>
<Tab heading="CLI" group="cli">

```shell-session
$ boundary host-sets create static -name "mysql-hosts" -description "MySQL host set" -host-catalog-id hcst_1234567890

Host Set information:
  Created Time:        Mon, 28 Sep 2025 18:27:10 PDT
  Description:         MySQL host set
  Host Catalog ID:     hcst_1234567890
  ID:                  hsst_z7gDCPSig5
  Name:                mysql-hosts
  Type:                static
  Updated Time:        Mon, 28 Sep 2025 18:27:10 PDT
  Version:             1

  Scope:
    ID:                p_1234567890
    Name:              Generated project scope
    Parent Scope ID:   o_1234567890
    Type:              project
```

</Tab>
<Tab heading="Terraform" group="terraform">

To define this host set in Terraform:

```hcl
resource "boundary_host_set_static" "mysql" {
  type            = "static"
  name            = "mysql-hosts"
  description     = "Host set for MySQL servers"
  host_catalog_id = "hcst_1234567890"
}
```

</Tab>
</Tabs>

#### Create the Postgres host set

Create a host set named `postgres-hosts` for the `postgres` host.

<Tabs>
<Tab heading="Admin Console" group="admin">

1. Log in to Boundary.
1. Select the org, and then select the project you want to create a host set for.
1. Select **Host Catalogs**.
1. Select the **databases** host catalog.
1. Click the **Host Sets** tab, and then click **New**.
1. Complete the following fields:
    - **Name**: `postgres-hosts` (Optional) An optional name for identification purposes.
    If you enter a name, it must be unique.
    - **Description**: (Optional) An optional description of the host catalog for identification purposes.
1. Click **Save**.

</Tab>
<Tab heading="CLI" group="cli">

```shell-session
$ boundary host-sets create static -name "postgres-hosts" -description "Postgres host set" -host-catalog-id hcst_1234567890

Host Set information:
  Created Time:        Mon, 28 Sep 2025 18:27:10 PDT
  Description:         Postgres host set
  Host Catalog ID:     hcst_1234567890
  ID:                  hsst_z7gDCPSig5
  Name:                postgres-hosts
  Type:                static
  Updated Time:        Mon, 28 Sep 2025 18:27:10 PDT
  Version:             1

  Scope:
    ID:                p_1234567890
    Name:              Generated project scope
    Parent Scope ID:   o_1234567890
    Type:              project
```

</Tab>
<Tab heading="Terraform" group="terraform">

To define this host set in Terraform:

```hcl
resource "boundary_host_set_static" "postgres" {
  type            = "static"
  name            = "postgres-hosts"
  description     = "Postgres host set"
  host_catalog_id = "hcst_1234567890"
}
```

</Tab>
</Tabs>

### Create hosts

Hosts can belong to a host catalog without being assigned to a host set, but you must add hosts to a host set before a target can connect to them.

#### Create the mysql hosts

<Tabs>
<Tab heading="Admin Console" group="admin">

1. Select **Host Catalogs**.
1. Select the **databases** host catalog.
1. Click the **Hosts** tab, and click **New**.
1. Complete the following fields:
    - **Name**: `mysql1` (Optional) An optional name for identification purposes.
    If you enter a name, it must be unique.
    - **Description**: (Optional) An optional description of the host catalog for identification purposes.
    - **Address**: `192.168.0.10` (Required) The host address, without specifying the protocol.
1. Click **Save**.

Repeat this process for the `mysql2` host, with an address of `192.168.0.11`.

</Tab>
<Tab heading="CLI" group="cli">

Create the `mysql1` host with address `192.168.0.1` within the `mysql-hosts` host catalog.

```shell-session
$ boundary host create static -name "mysql1" -description "MySQL host 1" -host-catalog-id hcst_1234567890 -address 192.168.0.10

    Host information:
      Created Time:        Fri, 27 May 2025 10:48:29 MDT
      Description:         MySQL host 1
      Host Catalog ID:     hcst_1234567890
      ID:                  hst_U1qYKzKfXO
      Name:                mysql1
      Type:                static
      Updated Time:        Fri, 27 May 2025 10:48:29 MDT
      Version:             1

      Scope:
        ID:                p_1234567890
        Name:              Generated project scope
        Parent Scope ID:   o_1234567890
        Type:              project

      Authorized Actions:
        no-op
        read
        update
        delete

      Attributes:
        address:           192.168.0.10
```

Repeat this process for the `mysql2` host, with an address of `192.168.0.11`.

```shell-session
$ boundary host create static -name "mysql2" -description "MySQL host 2" -host-catalog-id hcst_1234567890 -address 192.168.0.11

Host information:
  Created Time:        Fri, 27 May 2025 10:48:29 MDT
  Description:         MySQL host 2
  Host Catalog ID:     hcst_1234567890
  ID:                  hst_U1qYKzKfXO
  Name:                mysql2
  Type:                static
  Updated Time:        Fri, 27 May 2025 10:48:29 MDT
  Version:             1

  Scope:
    ID:                p_1234567890
    Name:              Generated project scope
    Parent Scope ID:   o_1234567890
    Type:              project

  Authorized Actions:
    no-op
    read
    update
    delete

  Attributes:
    address:           192.168.0.11
```

</Tab>
<Tab heading="Terraform" group="terraform">

To create the `mysql1` and `mysql2` hosts in Terraform:

```hcl
resource "boundary_host_static" "mysql1" {
  name            = "mysql1"
  description     = "MySQL Server host"
  address         = "192.168.0.10"
  host_catalog_id = boundary_host_catalog_static.databases.id
}

resource "boundary_host_static" "mysql2" {
  name            = "mysql2"
  description     = "MySQL Server host"
  address         = "192.168.0.11"
  host_catalog_id = boundary_host_catalog_static.databases.id
}
```

</Tab>
</Tabs>

#### Add the hosts to the MySQL host set

Now that you created the `mysql1` and `mysql2` hosts, add them to the `mysql-hosts` host set you created earlier.

<Tabs>
<Tab heading="Admin Console" group="admin">

1. Select **Host Catalogs**.
1. Select the **databases** host catalog.
1. Click the **Host Sets** tab, and select **postgres-hosts**.
1. Click the **Hosts** tab. 
1. Click the **Manage** drop-down menu, and select **Add Existing Host**.
1. Select the checkboxes for the `mysql1` and `mysql2` hosts.
1. Click **Add Hosts**.

</Tab>
<Tab heading="CLI" group="cli">

Provide the `mysql1` and `mysql2` host IDs to the `boundary host-sets add-hosts` command.

```shell-session
$ boundary host-sets add-hosts -id=hsst_X8gmzYXbO4 -host=hst_U1qYKzKfXO -host=hst_xoKMbUsmQw

Host Set information:
  Created Time:        Fri, 27 May 2025 10:51:02 MDT
  Description:         MySQL host set
  Host Catalog ID:     hcst_1234567890
  ID:                  hsst_X8gmzYXbO4
  Name:                mysql-hosts
  Type:                static
  Updated Time:        Fri, 27 May 2025 10:59:00 MDT
  Version:             2

  Scope:
    ID:                p_1234567890
    Name:              Generated project scope
    Parent Scope ID:   o_1234567890
    Type:              project

  Authorized Actions:
    no-op
    read
    update
    delete
    add-hosts
    set-hosts
    remove-hosts

  Host IDs:
    hst_U1qYKzKfXO
    hst_xoKMbUsmQw
```

</Tab>
<Tab heading="Terraform" group="terraform">

To add hosts to the `mysql-hosts` host set in Terraform:

```hcl
resource "boundary_host_set_static" "mysql" {
  type            = "static"
  name            = "mysql-hosts"
  description     = "Host set for MySQL servers"
  host_catalog_id = "hcst_1234567890"

  host_ids = [ boundary_host_static.mysql1.id, boundary_host_static.mysql2.id ]
}
```

</Tab>
</Tabs>

#### Create the postgres host within the postgres host set

Create the `postgres` host within the `postgres-hosts` host set.

If you're using the UI, you can create a host and add it to a host set in one operation.

<Tabs>
<Tab heading="Admin Console" group="admin">

1. Select **Host Catalogs**.
1. Select the **databases** host catalog.
1. Click the **Host Sets** tab, and select **postgres-hosts**.
1. Click the **Manage** drop-down, and select **Create and Add Host**.
1. Complete the following fields:
    - **Name**: `postgres` (Optional) An optional name for identification purposes. If you enter a name, it must be unique.
    - **Description**: (Optional) An optional description of the host catalog for identification purposes.
    - **Address**: `192.168.0.20` (Required) The host address, without specifying the protocol.
1. Click **Save**.

</Tab>
</Tabs>

If you're using the CLI or Terraform, you must create the host before you can add it to a host set.

<Tabs>
<Tab heading="CLI" group="cli">

Create the `postgres` host with address `192.168.0.20` within the `postgres-hosts` host catalog.

```shell-session
$ boundary host create static -name "postgres" -description "Postgres host" -host-catalog-id hcst_1234567890 -address 192.168.0.20

Host information:
  Created Time:        Fri, 27 May 2025 11:48:29 MDT
  Description:         Postgres host
  Host Catalog ID:     hcst_1234567890
  ID:                  hst_FrdNPd9Zm9
  Name:                postgres
  Type:                static
  Updated Time:        Fri, 27 May 2025 11:48:29 MDT
  Version:             1

  Scope:
    ID:                p_1234567890
    Name:              Generated project scope
    Parent Scope ID:   o_1234567890
    Type:              project

  Authorized Actions:
    no-op
    read
    update
    delete

  Attributes:
    address:           192.168.0.20
```

Add the `postgres` host to the `postgres-hosts` host set you created earlier.

```shell-session
$ boundary host-sets add-hosts -id=hsst_z7gDCPSig5 -host=hst_FrdNPd9Zm9

Host Set information:
  Created Time:        Fri, 27 May 2025 10:51:02 MDT
  Description:         Postgres host set
  Host Catalog ID:     hcst_1234567890
  ID:                  hsst_X8gmzYXbO4
  Name:                postgres-hosts
  Type:                static
  Updated Time:        Fri, 27 May 2025 10:59:00 MDT
  Version:             2

  Scope:
    ID:                p_1234567890
    Name:              Generated project scope
    Parent Scope ID:   o_1234567890
    Type:              project

  Authorized Actions:
    no-op
    read
    update
    delete
    add-hosts
    set-hosts
    remove-hosts

  Host IDs:
    hst_FrdNPd9Zm9
```

</Tab>
<Tab heading="Terraform" group="terraform">

Create the `postgres` hosts in Terraform:

```hcl
resource "boundary_host_static" "postgres" {
  name            = "postgres"
  description     = "Postgres Server host"
  address         = "192.168.0.20"
  host_catalog_id = boundary_host_catalog_static.databases.id
}
```

Create the `postgres-hosts` host set and add the `postgres` host in Terraform:

```hcl
resource "boundary_host_set_static" "postgres" {
  type            = "static"
  name            = "postgres-hosts"
  description     = "Host set for Postgres servers"
  host_catalog_id = "hcst_1234567890"

  host_ids = [ boundary_host_static.postgres.id ]
}
```

</Tab>
</Tabs>

### Create a target

Targets define how a client should connect to a host within a host set.

Targets can set a direct target address to avoid using host catalogs. While this is useful for testing, at scale it becomes unmanageable to create and maintain separate targets for each host within a host set.

Host sets are assigned to targets to allow clients to connect to any available host in the host set.

Targets define the protocol and port used for a session with a host.

#### Create the mysql target

<Tabs>
<Tab heading="Admin Console" group="admin">

Create the `mysql` target with a default port of `3306`. 

1. Select **Targets** and click **New**.
1. Complete the following fields:
    - **Name**: `mysql` (Optional) An optional name for identification purposes. If you enter a name, it must be unique.
    - **Description**: (Optional) An optional description of the host catalog for identification purposes.
    - **Type**: `Generic TCP` (Required)
    - **Default Port**: `3306` (Required)
1. Click **Save**.

Add the `mysql-hosts` host set as the host source for the target.

1. Select the **Host Sources** tab.
1. Click **Add Host Sources**.
1. Select the checkboxes for the `mysql-hosts` host set.
1. Click **Add Host Sources**.

</Tab>
<Tab heading="CLI" group="cli">

Create the `mysql` target with a default port of `3306`. 

```shell-session 
$ boundary targets create tcp -name="mysql" -description="MySQL target" -default-port=3389 -scope-id=p_1234567890 -session-connection-limit="-1" -host-source

Target information:
  Created Time:               Fri, 27 May 2025 11:02:22 MDT
  Description:                MySQL target
  ID:                         ttcp_34yV5O9cwt
  Name:                       mysql
  Session Connection Limit:   -1
  Session Max Seconds:        28800
  Type:                       tcp
  Updated Time:               Fri, 27 May 2025 11:02:22 MDT
  Version:                    1

  Scope:
    ID:                p_1234567890
    Name:              Generated project scope
    Parent Scope ID:   o_1234567890
    Type:              project

  Authorized Actions:
    no-op
    read
    update
    delete
    add-host-sources
    set-host-sources
    remove-host-sources
    add-credential-libraries
    set-credential-libraries
    remove-credential-libraries
    add-credential-sources
    set-credential-sources
    remove-credential-sources
    authorize-session

  Attributes:
    Default Port:             3306
```

Add the `mysql-hosts` host set as the host source for the target.

```shell-session
$ boundary targets add-host-sources -id=ttcp_34yV5O9cwt -host-source=hsst_X8gmzYXbO4

Target information:
  Created Time:               Fri, 27 May 2025 11:02:22 MDT
  Description:                MySQL target
  ID:                         ttcp_34yV5O9cwt
  Name:                       mysql
  Session Connection Limit:   -1
  Session Max Seconds:        28800
  Type:                       tcp
  Updated Time:               Fri, 27 May 2025 11:07:59 MDT
  Version:                    2

  Scope:
    ID:                p_1234567890
    Name:              Generated project scope
    Parent Scope ID:   o_1234567890
    Type:              project

  Authorized Actions:
    no-op
    read
    update
    delete
    add-host-sources
    set-host-sources
    remove-host-sources
    add-credential-libraries
    set-credential-libraries
    remove-credential-libraries
    add-credential-sources
    set-credential-sources
    remove-credential-sources
    authorize-session

  Host Sources:
    Host Catalog ID:          hcst_1234567890
    ID:                       hcst_xM3iCCkf1K

  Attributes:
    Default Port:             3306
```

</Tab>
<Tab heading="Terraform" group="terraform">

Create the `mysql` target with a default port of `3306` and add the `mysql-hosts` host set as the host source.

```hcl
resource "boundary_target" "mysql" {
  type                     = "tcp"
  name                     = "mysql"
  description              = "MySQL target for mysql-hosts host catalog"
  scope_id                 = boundary_scope.project.id
  session_connection_limit = -1
  session_max_seconds      = 300
  default_port             = 5432
  host_source_ids = [
    boundary_host_set_static.mysql.id
  ]
}
```

</Tab>
</Tabs>

#### Create the postgres target

<Tabs>
<Tab heading="Admin Console" group="admin">

1. Select **Targets** and click **New**.
1. Complete the following fields:
    - **Name**: `postgres` (Optional) An optional name for identification purposes. If you enter a name, it must be unique.
    - **Description**: (Optional) An optional description of the host catalog for identification purposes.
    - **Type**: `Generic TCP` (Required)
    - **Default Port**: `5432` (Required)
1. Click **Save**.

Add a host source.

1. Select the **Host Sources** tab.
1. Click **Add Host Sources**.
1. Select the checkboxes for the `postgres-hosts` host set.
1. Click **Add Host Sources**.

</Tab>
<Tab heading="CLI" group="cli">

Create the `postgres` target with a default port of `5432`. 

```shell-session 
$ boundary targets create tcp -name="postgres" -description="Postgres target" -default-port=5432 -scope-id=p_1234567890 -session-connection-limit="-1"

Target information:
  Created Time:               Fri, 27 May 2025 11:02:22 MDT
  Description:                Postgres target
  ID:                         ttcp_ge1Mowyrej
  Name:                       mysql
  Session Connection Limit:   -1
  Session Max Seconds:        28800
  Type:                       tcp
  Updated Time:               Fri, 27 May 2025 11:02:22 MDT
  Version:                    1

  Scope:
    ID:                p_1234567890
    Name:              Generated project scope
    Parent Scope ID:   o_1234567890
    Type:              project

  Authorized Actions:
    no-op
    read
    update
    delete
    add-host-sources
    set-host-sources
    remove-host-sources
    add-credential-libraries
    set-credential-libraries
    remove-credential-libraries
    add-credential-sources
    set-credential-sources
    remove-credential-sources
    authorize-session

  Attributes:
    Default Port:             5432
```

Add the `postgres-hosts` host set as the host source for the target.

```shell-session
$ boundary targets add-host-sources -id=ttcp_ge1Mowyrej -host-source=hsst_z7gDCPSig5

Target information:
  Created Time:               Fri, 27 May 2025 11:02:22 MDT
  Description:                Postgres target
  ID:                         ttcp_ge1Mowyrej
  Name:                       postgres
  Session Connection Limit:   -1
  Session Max Seconds:        28800
  Type:                       tcp
  Updated Time:               Fri, 27 May 2025 11:07:59 MDT
  Version:                    2

  Scope:
    ID:                p_1234567890
    Name:              Generated project scope
    Parent Scope ID:   o_1234567890
    Type:              project

  Authorized Actions:
    no-op
    read
    update
    delete
    add-host-sources
    set-host-sources
    remove-host-sources
    add-credential-libraries
    set-credential-libraries
    remove-credential-libraries
    add-credential-sources
    set-credential-sources
    remove-credential-sources
    authorize-session

  Host Sources:
    Host Catalog ID:          hcst_1234567890
    ID:                       hsst_X8gmzYXbO4

  Attributes:
    Default Port:             5432
```

</Tab>
<Tab heading="Terraform" group="terraform">

Create the `postgres` target with a default port of `5432` and add the `postgres-hosts` host set as the host source.

```hcl
resource "boundary_target" "postgres" {
  type                     = "tcp"
  name                     = "postgres"
  description              = "Postgres target for postgres-hosts host catalog"
  scope_id                 = boundary_scope.project.id
  session_connection_limit = -1
  session_max_seconds      = 300
  default_port             = 5432
  host_source_ids = [
    boundary_host_set_static.postgres.id
  ]
}
```

</Tab>
</Tabs>

You should now be able to start a session for any of these targets using the CLI or Boundary Desktop Client. If these hosts actually existed at these addresses, you would be able to connect.

## More information

Refer to [Filtering and listing resources](/boundary/docs/filtering) for more information about Boundary's filter syntax and best practices.

To learn about how to connect to a target, refer to the [Connection workflows](/boundary/docs/targets/connections) documentation.
